description: Dive into "Snapshots of George Town's Hidden Gems" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Snapshots of George Town's Hidden Gems

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the natural landscapes of Waterfall River Valley, Penang Botanic Gardens is a 30-hectare public park featuring a diverse range of botanical exhibits. Despite being commonly known as 'Waterfall Gardens,' there's no actual waterfall within the park. However, visitors can still enjoy exploring the extensive tropical rainforest, rare species of ferns, an herb garden, and an orchidarium.

sources.snippet: The Botanical Gardens is a very popular place for Penangnites to go working out and jogging, brisk walking, do taichi etc. Many people, however, don‚Äôt know that there‚Äôs a beautiful hidden spot at the top of the hill inside the gardens. Vernon of Momento Wedding Photography suggests going at the beginning of the year when the weather is a bit hotter.
sources.shortName: 27 Stunning Locations for Your Pre Wedding Photography in Penang

sources.snippet: Penang Botanic Gardens is the most beautiful park situated in Penang. A famous spot for locals to exercise, the park consists of numerous types of trees, and plants. Fondly known as Waterfalls Gardens, you will find a waterfall on top, followed by a river flowing through the park.
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: Visit the Penang Botanical Gardens for a stroll or climb Penang Hill for an incredible view. There's also a cable car ride to the top if hiking feels a bit ambitious. If it's a day of sand and sun that you seek, head northwest by car or taxi to Monkey Beach or Batu Ferringhi.
sources.shortName: 10 Photos That Prove Georgetown is the Cutest City in Malaysia

sources.snippet: If you are done with street photo you will have other option. For example, the Botanic Garden, one of the places worth photographing Georgetown. Located at Jalan Kebun Bunga, it is Malaysia‚Äôs only botanic garden, boasting a great and artistic landscape.
sources.shortName: Guide to photographing Georgetown Penang

places.name: Botanical Gardens Penang

reviews.text: Beautiful place to experience the tropical nature. It has many areas to explore and enjoy. I liked the Curtis trail through the jungle and started my hike towards Penang hill via Station 46 from the gardens.

More a park than a botanical garden. It's free. Some areas are not very well-maintained. That said, it's still a pleasant place for a walk or a run, and we were lucky to spot a dusky leaf monkey, which was definitely a highlight. You don't need much time here-about an hour to an hour and a half is enough to explore.

Penang Botanical Gardens is a beautiful and peaceful escape right outside the city. The grounds are well-kept, full of lush greenery, and home to a surprising variety of plants and  wildlife.

It's a great place for a morning walk, light hike, or just to enjoy nature.

Highly recommend visiting if you want a break from the bustle of George Town. A perfect spot for both locals and travelers to recharge in nature.

places.address: Kompleks Pentadbiran,Bangunan Pavilion, Jalan Kebun Bunga, 10350 George Town, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Kek Lok Si Temple, located on the White Crane Mountain in Penang, Malaysia, is the largest Chinese Buddhist temple in the country. Built in 1889, it showcases a blend of architectural styles from China, Thailand, and Myanmar. The temple complex is divided into lower, middle, and hilltop sections featuring intricate decor and numerous Buddha images. Visitors can explore various religious and cultural structures as well as beautifully landscaped gardens.

sources.snippet: Kek Lok Si Temple in Air Itam is probably the most well-known attraction in all of Penang, and for good reason ‚Äì it‚Äôs one of the biggest Buddhist temples in South East Asia. Here, you‚Äôll be blessed with so many great photo opportunities around every corner ‚Äì making it one of the great Penang photography spots. And the most important part, it‚Äôs free to visit!
sources.shortName: 6 Amazing Penang Photography Spots For Unique Photos

sources.snippet: When I decided to go to Penang, I did not expect to stumble across something so stunning. The Kek Lok Si temple is much, much larger than I expected, and extremely underrated. I highly recommend everyone visiting Penang to set aside a day to visit (and photograph) the Kek Lok Si temple.
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Spots in Penang, Malaysia

sources.snippet: There are two things that you must do when you visit Penang. a) eat Air Itam‚Äôs famous laksa, and b) visit the largest Buddhist temple in Malaysia. Driving through Air Itam, it is hard to miss the large Goddess of Mercy statue that is 120 feet tall.
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: When in Air Itam, don‚Äôt forget to pay Kek Lok Si temple a visit. Surrounded by beautiful gardens and ponds, walk around in peace and tranquility and let the stresses wear off before finding your ideal shot
sources.shortName: 19 Penang Instagrammable Spots Worthy Of Your Feed

sources.snippet: Kek Lok Si Temple in Penang, Malaysia, is considered a top photo spot for several reasons: 1.) Architectural Grandeur: Kek Lok Si Temple is one of the largest Buddhist temples‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: Best Photo and Photography Spots in Penang

sources.snippet: One of the tourist attractions and places to go when in Penang is the Kek Lok Si Temple. Here are the photos I took with my Yashica film camera and my Fujifilm.
sources.shortName: Cuti-Cuti Georgetown, Penang - Eat, Sleep & Photo Walk

sources.snippet: This temple is one of the largest Buddhist religious site in South East Asia and each corner has its own charming style that‚Äôs worth taking pictures of.
sources.shortName: 10 Instagrammable Spots in Penang You Have to Check Out!
20 Beautiful Places in Penang to Feed Your Instagram
Penang Photography - Photo gallery, map of the top spots and suggested gear - MEL365.com

places.name: Kek Lok Si Temple

reviews.text:
We visited on 31 March 2025.
A public holiday. Very bad traffic jam towards the temple. We parked at the 1st car park at base level. We didn't know that we could drive up to the different levels and pay parking there too. At base level, you can take the lift (funicular) at RM$3 per person to go up to mid level. RM$3 for the down ride. Total RM$6 person.

The 15 minute walk up to the mid level was not nice as there was no proper walking path or signage & the hot weather made it worse. You can drive up and park at mid level. From mid level, same thing applies. Lift (funicular) RM$3 per person to go up top level to view the large Goddess of Mercy. RM$3 to come down. Unfortunately, the Goddess of Mercy area was closed for upgrading works. At the top level, you get a nice view and there's a temple too. You can also drive up to top level and it's paid parking.

The pagoda area is worth a visit too. RM$2 per person. It's at the mid level and a short walk only.

It is a beautiful temple and a must visit place. We enjoyed ourselves and you can spend up to 2hrs there. Wear slip on walking shoes is best.

Enjoy ü•≥

Recommended but with some negatives.

Pros: still plenty of beauty in the buildings and grounds. Nice viewpoints. Staff are friendly and helpful.

Cons: It's chaotic. The lower tram isn't working so they put you in a mini van to get to the next level up, then a golf cart to the upper tram. There's no map or guide to help you, and signage is confusing. There's a walk up and through gardens that would have been better than the golf cart. There's no way for first time visitors to understand the layout.

They want you to go through the stores and you'll miss the best parts on the middle levels if you aren't careful. Take your time to explore all the directions.

It's quite commercialized. Selling stuff I the Temples seems a little weird.

A must in Penang.

This vast temple boasts stunning architecture. I think it's the most beautiful Chinese temple in Penang. Don't miss the pagoda and the large Guan Yin statue. There are three levels. I recommend walking up level 1 and taking the elevator up levels 2 and 3. It's definitely worth a visit.

places.address: 86s, Jln Balik Pulau, 11500 Air Itam, Penang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Hin Bus Depot, a former bus terminal transformed into a vibrant cultural center, offers a unique blend of indoor and outdoor art exhibitions, along with a cozy cafe and weekend market. The depot's spacious grounds host multimedia exhibition spaces, artistic workshops, cinema screenings, concerts, and pop-up craft markets on Sundays. This contemporary art space showcases progressive artists and artworks within its renovated art-deco buildings. Visitors can also admire murals by renowned artist Ernest Zacharevic that adorn the walls of the depot.

sources.snippet: It was once an old bus depot but now it has been transformed into an art exhibition spot, complete with a cafe, and weekend market. It is always a great idea to drop by during the weekends to check out knick-knacks!. Roam around to find interesting murals in different corners of the depot.
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: Originally a bus depot, this place has now transformed into a unique creative art space. There are instagram-worthy cafes here as well as several spots where you can take your #ootd shots. Click here to read Chinese article
sources.shortName: 10 Instagrammable Spots in Penang You Have to Check Out!

sources.snippet: Once a derelict bus station, the Hin Bus Depot is now among Penang‚Äôs trendiest places. Stepping inside transports you to a world of transformative murals, curious exhibits and chic cafes.
sources.shortName: 19 Penang Instagrammable Spots Worthy Of Your Feed

sources.snippet: Hin Bus Depot in Penang, Malaysia, has gained popularity as a photo spot for professional photoshoots due to several reasons: 1.) Industrial and Artistic Atmosphere: Hin Bus Depot is a‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: Best Photo and Photography Spots in Penang
20 Beautiful Places in Penang to Feed Your Instagram

places.name: Hin Bus Depot

reviews.text: Great spot for some shopping, hand made goods, some fresh food made on the spot in the market, great drinks and some wonderful live music and dj's. The feeling on Saturday and Sunday is quite different so we can for both. Loved Sunday with the live bands to sit out in the sun in the afternoon enjoying a nice drink with great music and friends.

What a fantastic experience visiting Hin Bus Depot. The space is vibrant and full of life, with plenty of artwork to admire and appreciate, from murals and installations to smaller creative pieces.

I was lucky enough to catch a couple of live performances during my visit, which added to the charm of the place. There was also a lively market happening at the time, with large variety of items for sale like artwork, plants, clothes, and even nostalgic finds like old books, tiffin carriers, vintage phones and records.

Food options are available too, with a decent variety to suit different tastes. I'd highly recommend visiting over the weekend when there's more going on, though do expect a bit of a crowd. If you're someone who enjoys art, local culture and discovering hidden gems, this is definitely a spot worth checking out.

Went there on the weekend where the market features a variety of stalls with everything from handmade crafts and vintage finds to clothes, plants, and collectibles. For art lovers, it's a perfect spot to explore local artists' work and discover one-of-a-kind pieces.

The lively atmosphere is further enhanced by live performances and music, making it a great spot to hang out with friends or family.

Though the market can get a little crowded, the overall vibe is fun and relaxed, and there's plenty to see and enjoy.

places.address: 31A, Jalan Gurdwara, 10300 George Town, Penang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: The Habitat Penang Hill is a must-visit attraction on the island, offering an educational and enjoyable experience in the pristine rainforest. Visitors can explore the lush tropical rainforest, learn about its flora and fauna, and take short nature trails. The highlight is the treetop and canopy walk that provides a unique perspective of the area.

sources.snippet: Located on the top of Penang Hill, The Habitat has several experiences for you to discover. Catch the best sunsets while you are walking on Sunset Walk, and climb all the way up Curtis Crest Tree Top Walk to be on top of the world!. Or, just stroll around and learn one or two things about 130 million-year-old rainforest.
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: A trip to Penang Hill will not be complete without a visit to The Habitat. There‚Äôs plenty you can do here: Head up the Curtis Crest and take stunning shots of the surrounding vistas.
sources.shortName: 19 Penang Instagrammable Spots Worthy Of Your Feed

places.name: The Habitat Penang Hill

reviews.text:
The place is stunning! You can easily spend there the whole day simply enjoying the nature. And that's what it was mean for. There're benches to rest, there're water refilling free stations, and there're stunning views!

Also, you may be lucky to observe monkeys, as they live they're and have a trail thought the park.

Grab your water bottle, and come spend at least a few hours just wandering around.

Foreigner adult ticket is MYR 60 and it surely worth it!

Our visit to the Habitat and evening walk inside it, was on 27June2025.
I have mixed reviews for my experience, but generally dissapointed and short of my expectations. Our experience at The Habitat was both wonderful (for the exploration & views) & horrific (dark, unsafe, unguarded during the evening)
ü§ëüí∏ For Rm60 for entrance + rm18 for evening walk (per pax), this place is poorly managed in terms of customers safety & expectations. That explains why there were very few visitors entering here at that hour.(I am unsure for the other times of the day of other days)
üëª Evening around 7.45pm, for about 10 mins walk out to the exit, with no one else in sight, just darkness (a few small little lights on the side walk), the jungle and its sounds, it was scary & spooky. Only saw more lights when we reahed the Langur way canopy walk.
üëé Some areas were badly maintained & lighting was really bad. Probably they want to ensure the area is kept wild and dark for the animals' natural habitat, that is understandable.
üò∞ However, there should have staff at checkpoints along the way to ensure visitors' safety & assurance that they are on the right path.
üëΩ When we finally arrive at the entrance, the staff hut (ticketing place) was dark, empty & we saw the huge gate was closed! Suddenly a tall dark man appeared & we though he was another visitor or a guard who will tell us that we are at the wrong place for exit! To our relief, he was indeed a staff or a person guarding the gat& he opened the gate for us.
ü§© Alhamdulillah, we made it out safely. I was a bit shake.
At this point, I would not recommend paying extra for the evening walk, unless there is a good crowd of visitors and proper guide along the way by the staff on duty.

Had an amazing time at The Habitat Penang Hill!

The Tree Top Walk was absolutely breathtaking-standing at the highest point in Penang with 360-degree panoramic views was unforgettable.

The Canopy Walk was another highlight, letting me stroll above the rainforest and really take in the beauty of the surroundings. Both walks felt safe, well-maintained, and offered unique perspectives of Penang's ancient rainforest. It may seem a bit pricey at first, but the experience is totally worth the money for the views and the serenity.

Highly recommended for anyone visiting Penang Hill!

places.address: C7G9+69, Bukit Bendera, 11300 Bukit Bendera, Penang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: BookXcess Gurney Paragon is a beautiful bookstore in Penang that is perfect for Instagramming. With towering shelves and a million books, it's a must-visit for bookworms and photographers alike.

sources.snippet: The largest bookstore in the Northern Region is the latest addition to Instagram-worthy spots in Penang. Having the tallest and longest bookshelves in Malaysia, BookXcess at Gurney Paragon houses one million books. Not only is it compulsory for bookworms to visit, but photographers will find irresistible too!
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: Taking instaworthy pictures in beautiful bookstores is all the rage right now. And in Penang, nowhere is it more trendy to do so than in BookXcess Gurney Paragon. Featuring a two-storey bookshelf, one of Malaysia‚Äôs longest, snap the perfect shot to fill your feed with.
sources.shortName: 19 Penang Instagrammable Spots Worthy Of Your Feed

places.name: BookXcess Gurney Paragon

reviews.text: This place is so big. So spacious, so many books. They even have a dedicated space for children books. Found some board games here.

Bookworms Heaven!!! Many types of difference subject books can be found at here. The books mostly in English version and brand new. Buy a favourite book and reading on the sofa with cosy atmosphere. The book prices is reasonable and cheap, thank u very much.

A book lover's paradise!
BookXcess is a spacious and beautifully decorated bookstore with a calming atmosphere that makes you want to stay for hours. They offer a huge variety of books across every genre - from business, fiction, food and cooking, to lifestyle, self-help, kids, music, religion, and more. The layout is inviting and easy to explore. A great place to discover hidden gems or just enjoy some peaceful browsing time. Highly recommended for readers of all ages!

places.address: 163D-7.06-7.16 & L8.02-8.-5, Gurney Paragon, Persiaran Gurney, 10250 George Town, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: The Pinang Peranakan Mansion is a captivating heritage museum that provides insight into the Peranakans' way of life. This community comprises descendants of Chinese immigrants who settled in the Malay archipelago between the 15th and 17th centuries. The mansion, a meticulously restored ancestral home, displays an impressive array of antiques and artifacts that illustrate the cultural blend of local Malay, Indian, Chinese, and European influences.

sources.snippet: The Pinang Peranakan Mansion is an old mansion turned museum that, according to Vernon from Momento Wedding Photography, has a beautiful oriental vintage theme for a pre wedding photoshoot. The interior is full of old antiques and testifies the truly unique old Penang Baba-Nyonya culture ‚Äî a fusion of Straits Chinese and Malay culture. Every corner of the mansion offers stunning opportunities to create very elegant touches in every pre wedding photos.
sources.shortName: 27 Stunning Locations for Your Pre Wedding Photography in Penang

sources.snippet: I really enjoyed visiting two mansions where once prominent members of the George Town community lived: the Pinang Peranakan Mansion and the Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion (also known as ‚ÄòThe Blue Mansion‚Äô). The first one you can explore by yourself after paying the admission fee. For the Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion you need to join one of the daily tours.
sources.shortName: Photos That Will Make You Want to Visit George Town, Penang

sources.snippet: The green-hued mansion located at Church Street was once the residence and office of Chung Keng Quee, a 19th-century Chinese tycoon. Now, the mansion contains thousands of Peranakan artifacts. The beautiful spot was also featured in television shows such as The Little Nyonya!
sources.shortName: 15 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Penang That Aren't Street Art

sources.snippet: Take a walk down memory lane at Penang‚Äôs Peranakan Museum where you can marvel at Baba Nyonya antique and take gorgeous shots at the open patio.
sources.shortName: 10 Instagrammable Spots in Penang You Have to Check Out!
20 Beautiful Places in Penang to Feed Your Instagram

places.name: Pinang Peranakan Mansion

reviews.text:
From start to finish, everything about this visit was just right.

We got there to discover that a guided tour in English was due to start in less than 15 minutes, so we took a seat and waited, soaking up the atmosphere. Most people didn't choose to go on the tour, so we had a small group, which helped to personalise it.

Stanley was our guide, and he was extremely good, very practiced and slick. He knew so much about the history of the building, and had a few jokes and personal anecdotes, that helped to make it come alive.

The house itself is a wonder, giving a real glimpse into the lifestyle of a wealthy Chinese leader of the time. Some of the artworks were exquisite, and while too ornate for present day tastes, they gave an idea of the opulent lifestyle that a small number of people had.

There were many interesting tales, they didn't sugarcoat difficult historical situations either, explaining about foot binding and opium use, amongst others.

The thing that impressed me most however, it quite blew me away, was the jewellery made from kingfisher feathers. It represented about 3 years work by a craftsman, is over 100 years old, and still looks fresh.

Hopefully that gives a small taste of what the visit was like. It was the most interesting thing we did in Malaysia and for me it would be a definite must see if you spend some time in Georgetown.

We came here with main objective for Nonya kebaya dress up, and were amazed at the items in museum. Displayed were v detailed crafts by peranakans like beaded bags and shoes with super micro beads,  to antique furnitures which really brought us back to Little Nonya tv series site.

The Nonya kebaya rental, hairdo, makeup, photographers and museum ticket entry are at the little building opposite the museum.

important note:
Ensure your engaged photographer time slot is confirmed n written by staff onto your receipt before walking off Nonya Palazzo.
We learn it the hard way with a lot of time wasted.
Our photographer was double booked at our stipulated timing due to the mistake by the staff at counter.

We were told a photographer slot 2 hours later from our kebaya rental, which we proceed to make payment n set hairdo.

After loitering around at museum for 2 hours we came back for photographer and were told that his slot is for another couple.
The reason? Their procedure was to confirm timing after our hairdo and dress up so that the timing can be assigned. But this was NOT COMMUNICATED to us at all, and we were CONFIRMED AT STIPULATED TIME during payment. The staff still wrote my name on the list, but missed out writing in the timing.

The reassigned timing was 2 hours later from original time which by then would be 4 freaking hours wait just for photoshoot, due to front service staff mistake.

By then we were asking for full refund n ready to walk off, without the much anticipated photoshoot.

Some discussion went on with their boss and photographer managed to squeeze out time  & slot us in after the couple's.

The photography session went well and the photographer SL handled professionally, despite the arrangement mishap.
Highly recommend to have professional photographer as he will guide you for Nonya-applicable poses in museum :) which creates very good keepsake memory.

To museum front counter service staff, we respect your procedure but this isn't your insurance to keep telling customers only after things got screwed up and totally not mention at all prior.
Please communicate clearly to your customers, and ensure leave no stones unturned. People don't wait 4 hours just for a photography session when we could have arrange for other itinerary. If you had promised a certain timing, you don't flip your words and said that it was termed ‚Äúestimated‚Äù afterwhich, when it's you missed out on writing down the time onto your sheet.  We went for payment after your confirmed photography time slot. And not ‚Äúestimated‚Äù as claimed.

We visit on a weekday but the place is still busy. We waited 15 minutes to join a guided tour.  Although the group is large and it could be crowded, I still find it's interesting and learnt more about the place and its people. For the property itself, it's a proper mansion with spacious rooms, court yard, ancestral shrine and attached maids corner and kitchen.  There is an adjacent house that serves as jewellery and craft exhibition room. Overall it is a destination not to be missed.

places.address: 29, Church St, Georgetown, 10200 George Town, Penang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Armenian Street, nestled in the heart of George Town, is a vibrant tapestry of culture and creativity. As you wander along this historic lane, you'll encounter the stunning Kapitan Keling Mosque and an array of Chinese temples and clan houses that add to its multicultural charm. This street is not just about history; it‚Äôs also a hub for art enthusiasts.

sources.snippet: The next area is the near Armenian Street You can stroll past the Kapitan Keling Mosque and visit the various Chinese Temples and Clan Houses that surround the street.Aside from the temples and Mosques, Armenian Street is where you can kick off your street art tour to see the famous street art of Penang. Every saturday evening, Armenian Street comes alive with locals selling arts and crafts, live music and even plays are had.
sources.shortName: Guide to photographing Georgetown Penang

sources.snippet: The interior of the church is equally, if not more beautiful than the outside. However, if you plan on updating your Instagram feed with pictures of the church interior, make sure you observe the rules and respect the sensitivities of the church.
sources.shortName: 20 Beautiful Places in Penang to Feed Your Instagram

places.name: Armenian Street

reviews.text: Armenian Street is very vibrant. There are many stores that sell interesting accessories, food and drinks, and various interesting things that can be explored. The streets here are very aesthetic and the best time to visit is in the afternoon. Because the light is good for photos.

üåÜ Armenian Street & Little India ‚Äì A Cultural Walk in Penang | TDC Khanabadosh**

Our journey through **George Town, Penang** took us on a beautiful walk that blended **history, culture, art, and flavors**-starting from **Armenian Street** and flowing into the vibrant heart of **Little India**.

üèõÔ∏è Armenian Street:
A stroll through Armenian Street is like flipping through a living history book. Lined with colorful shophouses and colonial-era architecture, it's famous for its **interactive street art**, like the iconic *Children on a Bicycle* mural. The lane is buzzing with **local art studios, antique shops, and heritage caf√©s**-perfect for travelers who love slow exploration and photography.

We couldn't resist stopping by a cozy caf√© for some **Penang white coffee**, before heading toward our next cultural stop...

üé∂ Little India:
As we stepped into Little India, everything changed-**the aroma of spices**, the sound of **Bollywood music**, and the burst of **sarees, bangles, and flower garlands**. It felt like we had entered a mini Chennai or Mumbai. The streets are alive with **Indian restaurants, sweet shops**, and colorful stores selling traditional wear.

We grabbed a quick plate of **dosas and mango lassi**, watched locals dancing to temple drums, and even picked up some **bindis and bangles** as souvenirs. The energy was infectious!

üí° **Mini Travel Idea: ‚ÄúTwo Cultures, One Walk‚Äù Challenge**
Plan a **walking tour from Armenian Street to Little India**, and:
‚úîÔ∏è Capture at least 3 murals
‚úîÔ∏è Try one local snack in each area
‚úîÔ∏è Collect a small souvenir that represents both cultures
‚úîÔ∏è End your walk at the Kapitan Keling Mosque or Sri Mahamariamman Temple to reflect on Penang's peaceful diversity

üé• Catch the full cultural journey** on our YouTube channel: **TDC Khanabadosh ‚Äì Travelling Desi Couple**
üìç Watch now:
üõéÔ∏è Don't forget to like, share, and subscribe for more travel stories!
Nice track to visit. After you fill your stomach fully, it's time to burn them by walking in this street. Nice view, you may take pictures while enjoying the atmosphere there

places.address: Lbh Armenian, Georgetown, 10450 George Town, Penang, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Chew Jetty is a UNESCO historic site and a traditional stilt village by the sea, dating back to the 19th century. It's one of the last Chinese settlements on Penang Island, with wooden stilt houses built along a walkway. The location offers a unique and adventurous spot for proposals, with its rustic charm and picturesque views of colorful sunsets and boats tied to the docks.

sources.snippet: Chew Jetty is very conveniently within walking distance of the main area of Georgetown. One of six main Clan jetties in Georgetown, it‚Äôs also one of the coolest Penang photography spots. The morning I visited, I took some amazing photos and i‚Äôll always remember it from when I was backpacking Penang.
sources.shortName: 6 Amazing Penang Photography Spots For Unique Photos

sources.snippet: There are a few, but the Chew and Tan Jetties are my favorite. I felt like I was walking through a video game when exploring these jetties because I didn‚Äôt know they still existed IRL. Address: Chew Jetty, Weld Quay, 10300 George Town, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
sources.shortName: Most Instagrammable Spots in Penang, Malaysia

places.name: Chew Jetty

reviews.text: A fishermen village where you can walk around to observe their marine lives. You can also look for souvenirs to buy like cloth bag. pin badge, and cute little things. Walking to reach the end of the way to see the sea view with clear blue sky. The weather is nice, too.

We visited Chew Jetty close to sunset, and I must say-it was the perfect time. The heat of the day had mellowed, and the golden rays of the setting sun cast a magical glow over the entire jetty. The wooden houses on stilts, the gently rippling water, and the silhouettes of boats in the distance made it feel like I had stepped into a postcard.

Walking along the planks with the evening breeze brushing past, I felt completely at ease. There were fewer tourists at this hour, which gave us more time to soak in the peaceful charm and snap some really stunning photos without the crowds. The colors in the sky reflected beautifully off the water, adding to the calm, laid-back vibe of the place.

It's amazing how this historical clan jetty, with its rustic homes and narrow boardwalks, still stands strong amidst modern George Town. A mix of old-world charm and everyday life, all quietly coexisting over the water.

Definitely recommend coming around golden hour-it's cooler, calmer, and visually unforgettable.

Chew Jetty may be small, but it's still a nice place to explore. It has a unique charm and local vibe. I enjoyed walking through the wooden walkways and supporting the local shops. The souvenirs here are surprisingly affordable-definitely cheaper than in other touristy areas. Worth a quick visit if you're nearby!
